dict_list.paragraph: It is noteworthy that Miss Miller quotes another case, where a name suddenly obtruded itself, parallel to the emerging into consciousness of Chiwantopel, namely, A-ha-ma-ra-ma, with the feeling that it dealt with something Assyrian.[364] As a possible source of this, there occurred to her “Asurabama, who made cuneiform bricks,”[365] those imperishable documents made from clay: the monuments of the most ancient history. If it were not emphasized that the bricks are “cuneiform,” then it might mean ambiguously “wedged-shaped bricks,” which is more suggestive of our interpretation than that of the author.“Remember when Moses said to his servant, ‘I will not stop till I  reach the confluence of the two seas, or for eighty years will I  journey on.’“But when they reached their confluence they forgot their fish, and it  took its way in the sea at will.“And when they had passed on, Moses said to his servant, ‘Bring us our  morning meal, for now we have incurred weariness from this our  journey.’“He said, ‘What thinkest thou? When we repaired to the rock for rest,  then verily I forgot the fish; and none but Satan made me forget it,  so as not to mention it; and it hath taken its way in the sea in a  wondrous sort.’“He said, ‘It is this we were in quest of.’ So they both went back  retracing their footsteps.“Then found they one of our servants to whom we had vouchsafed our  mercy, and whom we had instructed with our knowledge;[369]“Moses said to him, ‘Shall I follow thee that thou teach me, for  guidance of that which thou hast been taught?’“He said, ‘Verily, thou canst by no means have patience with me; and  how canst thou be patient in matters whose meaning thou comprehendest  not?’”—Trans. Rodwell, page 188.
dict_list.question: What historical reference does Miss Miller make to a name that suddenly came to her consciousness, and what does she propose as a possible source for this name in the context of the text?
dict_list.answer: Miss Miller references a name that suddenly came to her consciousness, similar to the emergence of Chiwantopel. She proposes "Asurabama, who made cuneiform bricks," as a possible source for this name. These bricks are significant as they are "cuneiform" documents made from clay, which are monuments of the most ancient history.

dict_list.question:
How does the biblical servant explain the disappearance of the fish?

**ANSARTER:**
The biblical servant explains the disappearance of the fish by saying, "When we repaired to the rock for rest, then verily I forgot the fish; and none but Satan made me forget it, so as not to mention it; and it hath taken its way in the sea in a wondrous sort." He attributes the fish's disappearance to Satan causing him to forget about it.

**QUESTION:**
What does Moses suggest doing after they find a servant who has knowledge, and what is the servant's response?
dict_list.answer: Moses suggests following the servant to learn from him, saying, "Shall I follow thee that thou teach me, for guidance of that which thou hast been taught?" The servant responds that "Verily, thou canst by no means have patience with me; and how canst thou be patient in matters whose meaning thou comprehendest not?" indicating that Moses would struggle to understand and be patient with the mysteries the servant knows.
